wikipedia_page.main: William Stanyhurst (1601 – 1663) was a Belgian Jesuit of Irish parentage. He was a prolific author of Latin religious works, one of which, Dei immortalis in corpore mortali patientis historia, was widely popular, and was translated into many languages.

response: In the early 1590s he was invited to Spain by King Philip II, who became seriously ill. Stanihurst worked at the great alchemical laboratory in El Escorial. At the same time he informed the state on Catholics' interest in England. After his wife's death in 1602 he took holy orders, and became chaplain to the Archduke Albert of Austria in the Netherlands.  He had two sons, Peter and William Stanyhurst, both of whom became  Jesuits.
* William Stanyhurst (1602–1663), Belgian Jesuit, son of Richard
